Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Spectro-electrochemical and theoretical study of carbon dioxide up-conversion mechanisms using clathrate hydrates
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanism B Program (CSDMB) of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Christoph Rose-Petruck (PI) and Professor Hannes Jónsson (co-PI). Professors Rose-Petruck and Jónsson are faculty members in the Department of Chemistry at Brown University. The research project focuses on the electrochemical conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into useful chemicals. Interest in CO2 conversion has increased significantly in recent years, in response to the increasing demand for sustainable products that are not generated from fossil fuels. While much work is being done to advance these efforts, there are still major hurdles to overcome. One of these is the electro-chemical generation of hydrogen gas that constantly competes with the desired CO2 conversion processes. This competing reaction steals the current (flow of electrons) needed for the CO2 conversion and, in so doing, makes the processes inefficient and costly. To solve this problem, the investigator are conducting the electrochemical conversion of CO2 in snow-like water crystals called clathrate hydrates that can store large amounts of CO2. This "snow" is mixed with salts and water to form an electrically conducting "snow-slush". The use of this mixture for the electro-chemical conversion of CO2 dramatically reduces the competing generation of hydrogen gas, leading to greatly improved yields and reaction efficiency. This discovery has the potential to be transformative in terms of how the conversion of CO2 into value added products is conducted. The use of clathrate hydrates in this fashion is very new, and the reaction mechanisms that enable the success of the approach are unknown. Hence, the researchers are seeking a better understanding of how these reactions work and how they can be manipulated to optimize the yield of a particular desired product. The research activities include a collaborative partnership with the Research Instruments Corporation, a Rhode Island based company. This company is a partner for technology transfer from Brown University into the market place. Recruitment and mentoring of historically underrepresented groups is enhanced through the partnership with the Leadership Alliance.

The electrochemical reduction of CO2 into carbonaceous products is carried out in clathrate hydrate-loaded electrolytes. These reaction conditions strongly reduce the needed overpotential and change the product spectrum compared to that obtained with non-clathrate electrolytes. A spectrum of products is produced with low reduction potentials. The researchers hypothesize that reactions inside the clathrate hydrate structures are initiated by hydrogen-radical formation from clathrate water molecules as the clathrate crystals contact the working electrode. The experiments are combined with calculations of the reaction mechanisms and rates. These calculations are based on density functional theory of the electronic structure and minimum energy path calculations to estimate energy barriers for the various reaction steps and rate estimates based on harmonic transition state theory. The research investigates CO2 reduction mechanisms in electrolytes that include clathrate hydrates. The study provides a detailed insight into a new class of reaction mechanisms that use clathrates as water-based frameworks for high energy-efficient up-conversion of CO2 and other molecules. The activities include collaborative partners. The Research Instruments Corporation contributes strength in entrepreneurship and a partner for technology transfer from Brown University into the market place. Recruitment and mentoring of historically underrepresented groups is enhanced through the partnership with the Leadership Alliance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clathrate hydrates are snow-like water crystals that can store as much as 100X more CO2 than an equal amount of liquid water. Using aqueous electrolytes with clathrate hydrate the hydrogen evolution reaction that always competes with the carbon evolution reaction is largely suppressed and a spectrum of CO, C2, C3, and C4 products is produced with outstanding Faradaic Efficiency on a copper electrode at very small reduction potentials. The clathrate hydrate use in CO2 reduction is novel and the reaction mechanisms were unknown. We studied these mechanisms by optical spectroscopy in combination with theoretical simulations.

THE THEORETICAL WORK advanced simulation methods relevant to electrochemical reactions on metal surfaces. Specifically, the work demonstrated the usefulness of the implicit solvation model for describing hydrogen evolution reaction steps on platinum surfaces in comparison to reference calculations using extrapolation methods. Additional theoretical calculations were carried out on the formation of HCOOH and CO on copper (111), (100) and (110) surfaces in order to identify the mechanism and activation energy as a function of applied voltage.

THE EXPERIMENTAL WORK focused on the quantification of the CO2 reduction products on copper electrodes in the presence of clathrate hydrates in the electrolyte. We found that at an applied potential of -0.5 V(RHE) where usually hydrogen evolution dominates, the Faradaic efficiency of CO2 reduction was 67%, greatly exceeding that in a CO2 saturated solution without clathrates. Our experimental observations were modeled by a set of coupled differential equations describing the mass transport of CO2 and of ions through the diffusion layer in the vicinity of the copper electrode. The simulation results demonstrate that the increased CO2 concentration caused by clathrate is sustainable at the electrode at small applied potentials whereas CO2 depletion occurs at higher current densities caused by larger applied potentials.

We proposed that the high CO2 concentration in clathrate hydrates is the reason for the enhanced CO2 reduction rate, resulting from CO2 release from clathrate hydrates under the strong electric field of the electrolytic double layer (EDL) at the working electrode. The fields in the EDL destabilize the CO2 clathrate structure, effectively raising the free energy of the CO2 inside the clathrate cages and reducing the energy barrier for CO2 release. This results in a supersaturation of CO2 at the working electrode. In the process clathrates are not melted but converted to ice. As a result the CO2 release does not consume latent heat and is very energy efficient.

We proved this proposed mechanism: Attenuated Total Reflection Fourier Transform Infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy was used in order to measure the response of tetrahydrofuran (THF) guest molecules in clathrates within a few nanometers of the working electrode. We demonstrated that the clathrate destruction is not caused by heating.

THE INTELLECTUAL MERIT of the project is the demonstration that the implicit solvation model can now be used with confidence for faster simulations compared to methods that describe the water molecules more explicitly. Furthermore, the research lays the intellectual foundation for possible clathrate use in sustainable chemistry which could become a component of a sustainable carbon cycle. The experimental results describe the mechanisms for mass transport and enhanced CO2 up-conversion to useful feedstock molecules in clathrate hydrate electrolytes. Finally, the dissociation of purely electric field induced release of CO2 from clathrates is novel and has never been experimentally observed before.

THE BROADER SIGNIFICANCE is the project?s impact on sustainable chemistry, specifically CO2 capture, sequestration, and up-conversion. Since clathrates greatly increase the CO2 concentration in electrolytes compared to conventional fluids, reactant concentration and up-conversion are integrated into one clathrate working fluid without the need for energy-hungry gas compression. The electric-field driven clathrate destruction also could have implications for flow assurance in natural gas pipelines. One could imaging applying an electric potential between the fluid and the pipeline walls. A dielectric double layer would be established that, in turn, destabilizes the clathrates and releases the guest gas molecules. This might prevent the buildup of clathrates at the walls and/or reduce clathrates that have already attached to the walls.
